page.title: 14CHURCH: FARLEIGH HUNGERFORD
page.content: THE CHURCH IN FARLEIGH HUNGERFORD IS NAMED AFTER{ST. LEONARD,}THE PATRON SAINT OF PRISONERS. IT BELONGS TO THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND. IT IS SHAPED LIKE A CROSS, AND WAS BUILT BY THE HUNGERFORD FAMILY IN THE 14th-15th CENTURY. A NEW CHIMNEY HAS BEEN ADDED, AS THE CHURCH NOW HAS OIL HEATING. INSIDE THE CHURCH, AT THE BACK, THERE ARE TWO STAINED GLASS WINDOWS, NEAR WHICH STAND A PIPE ORGAN AND A FONT. BEHIND THE FONT ARE BELL ROPES TO THE THREE BELLS. THERE ARE 23 PEWS. OUTSIDE, BY THE DOOR, IS AN OLD SHOE SCRAPER, AND ON TOP OF THE CHURCH IS A WEATHER COCK. AN APPEAL HAS BEEN LAUNCHED FOR REPAIRS TO THE ROOF. THERE ARE 57 GRAVES, WHICH DATE BACK TO BEFORE THE CHURCH WAS BUILT. THE LARGE HOUSE NEXT TO THE CHURCH USED TO BE THE VICARAGE.
